segments.text: OK. To continue with acoustics in the blind, this may or may not be a worthwhile kind of thing to do.
But we have not investigated it very much.

And unfortunately, it's the kind of thing, while I've spent a modest amount of time on it and talked to some of the people involved with the blind, I'm afraid I've been somewhat of a cop out in trying to carry it to any kind of a conclusion.
This is one of the difficulties one gets when you're in an institution as small as Woods Hole that is isolated so far from a city where a large number of things are going on.
Our acoustics groups aren't big enough to really hire anybody for this game, and it's a little difficult for me to see how to work in this very much unless one goes into a
a much larger city or a place like Boston where one can work with a much larger group of people.
Now, I have just a few more questions to ask you, and then that'll take care of the interview.
First of all,
What's your impression of the present environmentalist movement?
Is this running?
It's running.
Oh, it is running.
My first thought with regards to the environmentalist movement is that the world as a whole has been most fortunate that Rachel Carson,
efforts and work in the Silent Spring and so forth occurred prior to the so-called energy crisis initiated by OPEC.
I'm afraid if it had been the other way around, no one would have paid any attention to the environmentalists.
Getting more specific, there's
probably no question but what environmental problems are very real, that the people who are involved with them go all the way from serious, thoughtful people to the lunatic fringe.
Oceanography has probably been very fortunate in having a
geophysics earth scientists in general have tended to be leaders in the environmental field.
I think oceanography can be very proud of the work they did do.
For example, much of the CO2 involved was initiated by oceanographers.
And in fact, that was, I believe, an important part of the
of the Indian Ocean Expedition, which probably Roger may well have talked about some of this much more knowingly than I have.
I am pretty well convinced that the ocean is an enormous place.
And if we use common sense, we can do a great deal of experimenting in the ocean.
And I mean social experimenting.
We're not going to...
wreck the ocean overnight any more than the Spanish explorers could wreck the Americas overnight.
They could play havoc in small areas.
But it took centuries to make any great impression on the Americas.
One example of this was I had
mentioned earlier in the work with Crossroads.
I think it was probably a wonderful thing that the United States and oceanographers became involved in those early nuclear weapons tests.

They're not the kinds of things I would like to see go on indefinitely, but so much was learned early in the game that helped provide the perspective that is necessary to work towards the final solution of the problem.
As far as oceanographers are concerned,
We, as a group, are probably too conservative.
We have not tried to make any more comprehensive.
To my way of thinking, we have not outlined comprehensive enough research at a large enough scale to make as big bites in the problem as we should.

example, if a serious 10-year program encompassing ocean engineering and social aspects of it as well as the more conventional, purely scientific aspects of oceanography and dumping and so forth were concerned, I think the nation would be far better off and science would profit a great deal.
For example, we know
There are many good conjectures and so forth.
We know very little about the feasibility of putting waste into very deep holes.
We know very little about how long, about the fate of waste in deep holes.
There has been
Almost no work in dumping sewage, for example, under the thermocline, where it gets out of the surface areas for certainly decades.
There are clearly pros and cons to this.
But in a situation such as Hawaii, where they have such an enormous amount of ocean around them,
that the beach is sloped so much.
It would seem this is a kind of an oceanographic experiment, a large scale oceanographic experiment that should be done.
And then if it turns out to work out well, it could be emulated other places.
If it doesn't work out well, it could.
But these are some of the kinds of things that I really believe we're wasting time.
Somehow or other, our leadership in the higher level Washington community
many of whom are composed of individuals within our own profession, I think are really rather sadly lacking in gumption and foresight.
I believe this is one of the problems with financing in oceanography, that in recent years oceanographers have not been posing
attacks on some of these problems on the scale where we might really learn something significant enough to alter the way society goes.
I believe the American public and Congress and so forth somehow or other directly or indirectly recognizes this.
And they don't want to have much to do with intermediary size experiments that don't stand a very much chance to come out with a very good clear yes or a very clear no.
If you had to name one accomplishment in your career as oceanographer, what would you name?
First, I would say, as we discussed last night, that that is not so much a difficult question as an indeterminate question.
I believe because there are completely different kinds of accomplishments which don't come under the same category.
In the sort of classical oceanographic public sense, I suppose my principal interest has tended to be
to make the undersea and the bottom of the ocean part of the real world.

And take it a little bit more out of the mythical, excuse me, not take it out of the mythical class, but to the mythical and social aspects of the literary aspects of the ocean to be able to incorporate it more in the analytical scientific category.
After all, the ocean is only three miles deep, and our reasons for not being better acquainted with it are primarily social rather than technical.
Anything of more lasting value, perhaps, I feel anything that can be done to make the world more stable is probably one of the most important things that can happen, and I feel that my
If any major contribution was probably part of the being involved in some useful way in the major revolution that went on in undersea warfare and underwater acoustics.
So I guess those are the two aspects I would mention.
You can cheat by mentioning two rather than one.
All right.
Is there anything you'd like to add to the tape?
I would like to discuss that with you just a little bit more.
One of the things is perhaps take advantage of your view of this thing and
block out, just mention a few of the principal kinds of events that have happened that I have felt have been significant to the field of oceanography.
Then look at the piece of paper in front of me under sort of different categories.
We don't need to
of what the Challenger expedition of a century ago was important, as well as many since.
What happened to the importance of the National Academy of Sciences in getting things going in oceanography?
It has been spasmodic, but it has been extremely important from the first committee
in the 20s.
The second committees in the 40s was not particularly effective.
But the report they put out in the latter part of the 50s, which was Oceanography 1960 to 1970, I think was a landmark kind of report.
Pulled oceanographers together and pulled the nation together in oceanography in an outstanding way.
One of the reasons it was so successful, of course, was that Sputnik was the press agent.
And that was an enormous help.
It opened up people's eyes.
It opened up people's coffers.
I've mentioned from time to time of the tremendous importance of equipment.
In my own case, I've tended to concentrate

quite a bit on the equipment, not from the standpoint of bolts and nuts, but from the standpoint that I believe progress in our field is a subtle combination of new ideas, new data, and new technology.
And our social system seems to be put together so that the
particularly in recent times, that new techniques, people think of that as engineering and not science.

This, I think, is an unfortunate decade or two of oceanography, which I hope we will get over and get back to being more problem-oriented and do whatever is necessary to learn more about Mother Earth and use her for better.
Trends to get global ships so that we could operate over the surface of the Earth pretty much where we wanted to is so terribly important.
I note that this morning's newspaper describes the first visit of a surface ship to the North Pole.
Three cheers for the Russians and the crew of the Arctic for their work.

and I hope this is what should be the first of more routine usage of the Arctic Ocean, which after all is one of our oceans, and to date has been much more an ocean of the poet than of the oceanographer.
The general trends towards higher resolution equipment
which, in a simpler fashion, is merely getting ourselves new glasses so that we can see more of what the ocean is like, should continue on indefinitely.
Stop.
Any more questions?
Nope.
What kinds of questions?
people and marine policy.
